title: M/S Dhruve Constructions Thr.Kalpesh vs Madhya Pradesh Electricity Board on 1 September, 2017
doc:
M/S Dhruve Constructions Thr.Kalpesh vs Madhya Pradesh Electricity Board on 1 September, 2017

Bench: S.C. Sharma, Alok Verma

                                    8

      HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH: BENCH AT INDORE
     BEFORE D.B. HON. MR. JUSTICE S.C. SHARMA AND HON.MR.
                   JUSTICE ALOK VERMA, JJ

                          C.R. No.244/2006


                M/S Dhurve Constructions      ...... Applicant
                           Versus
      Madhya Pradesh Electricity Board and another... Respondents


______________________________________________________
                         CORAM

      Hon'ble Shri Justice S.C. Sharma
      Hon'ble Shri Justice Alok Verma

      Whether approved for reporting ?


      Ms. Meena Chaphekar, learned counsel for the petitioner.
      Shri D.S.Panwar, learned counsel for the respondent.
________________________________________________________________
                             ORDER

01.09.2017 Per : S.C.Sharma, J:

The present revision under Section 19 of the Madhya Pradesh Madhyashtham Adhikaran Adhiniyam, 1983 has been filed being aggrieved by the order dated 30.06.2006 passed in Reference Case No.56/2003 by Madhya Pradesh Arbitration Tribunal, Bhopal.

2. The facts of the case reveals that the petitioner is registered A-III Class contractor and pursuant to the NIT issued by the department, he has offered his tender and was awarded the tender in question. The work order was issued on 07.02.98 and the petitioner successfully carried out the work on 31.12.1999. There was a dispute between the parties and therefore, the petitioner as per Clause 67 of the agreement between the parties submitted a reference to the executive engineer who was engineer as mentioned 8 in the Arbitration Clause and as the dispute was not decided within 90 days by the engineer. The petitioner preferred an application before the M.P.Artbitration Tribunal, Bhopal and the same was registered as reference case no.56/2003. The M.P.Arbitration Tribunal in paragraphs 9 to 14 as held as under:-

"9. Arbitration Clause 67 of the agreement reads as follows:-
Settlement of Disputes-Arbitration If any dispute or difference of any kind whatsoever shall arise between the Employer and the Contractor the Engineer and the Contractor in connection with, or arising out of the Contract, or the execution of the works, whether during the progress of the works or after their completion and whether before or after the termination, abandonment or breach of the Contract, it shall, in the first place, be referred to and settled by the Engineer who shall, within a period of ninety days after being requested by either party to do so give written notice of his decision to the Employer and the Contactor subject to Arbitration as hereinafter provided, such decision in respect of every matter so referred shall be final and binding upon the Employer and the Contractor and shall forthwith be given effect to by the Employer and by the Contractor, who shall proceed with the execution of the works with all due diligence whether he or the employer requires arbitration as hereinafter provided or not. If the Engineer has given written notice of his decision to the Employer and the contract and no claim to arbitration has been communicated to him by either the employer or the contractor within a period of ninety days from receipt of such notice, the said decision shall remain final and binding upon the Employer and the Contractor. If the Engineer shall fail to give notice of his decision, as aforesaid, within a period of ninety days after being requested as aforesaid, or if either the Employer or the Contractor be dissatisfied with any such decision, then and in any such case either the employer or the contractor may within ninety days after the receiving notice of such decision, or within ninety days after the expiration of the first named period of ninety days, as the case may be, require that the matter or matters in dispute be referred to arbitration as hereinafter provided. All disputes of differences in respect of which the decision, if any, of the Engineer has not become final 8 and binding as aforesaid shall be finally settled, through arbitration by the one Arbitrator appointed by Chief Engineer (Civil Project) M.P.E.B. under the Arbitration Act, 194,. Indian Arbitration and Reconciliation Act Ordinace 1996 with latest revision. The said Arbitrator/s shall have full power to open up revise and review any decision, opinion, direction, certificate or valuation of the Engineer. Neither party shall be limited in the proceedings before such arbitrator/s to the evidence or arguments put before the Engineer for the purpose of obtaining his said decision. No decision given by the Engineer in accordance with the forgoing provisions shall disqualify him from being called as a witness and giving evidence before the arbitrator/s on any matter howsoever relevant to the dispute or difference referred to arbitrator/s as aforesaid. The reference to arbitration may proceed notwithstanding that the works shall not then be or be alleged to be complete, provided always that the obligations of the Employer, the Engineer and the Contractor shall not be altered by reason of the arbitration being conducted during the progress of the works."

10. As per aforesaid clause the petitioner was required to submit his claims before the final authority i.e "Engineer"(Executive Engineer (Civil) in charge of the Division executing the work) as per definition given in Clause 31 of Special Condition of the agreement). We have curiously gone through the record submitted by both the parties. Not a single letter is filed on the record, which has been addressed to Executive Engineer (Civil) in charge of the Division executing the work. The only letter dt.23.10.2002 Ex.P-21 is on the record which has been addressed to Chief Engineer (Civil) P & D Project Chief Engineer T & D M.P. Electricity Board, Superintending Engineer (Civil) M.P.Electricity Board, the Chairman, M.P.Tourism Corporation Ltd., the Executive Engineer Mini Construction Division M.P.Electricity Board & State of Madhya Pradesh through Collector, Jabalpur. This letter also has not been addressed to Executive Engineer (Civil) as envisaged in clause 31 i.e. definition clause, therefore, arbitration clause 67 does not stand complied with and since the final authority has not been approached in terms of the contract the petition is not maintainable.

11. An Order passed by full Bench of Hon'ble M.P.High Court (Gwalior) in Civil Revision 8 No.692/1998 State of M.P. and another Vs. Kamal Kishore Sharma dt.13.09.2005 needs to be referred hear with a view to consider the adjudicability of the petition. We quote para 16 of order "Considering the provisions of Section 7-B(1)(a) we are of the opinion that on interpreting the provisions of Section 7-B(1) it is crystal clear that no reference shall be admitted by the Tribunal unless dispute is first referred for the decision of the final authority in a manner as provided under the terms of the contract. Thus right of contractor to approach Tribunal arises after he has approached final authority after decision of Superintending Engineer in terms of the contract. If the contractor has failed to approach the final authority as provided under the terms and conditions of the works contract, petition will not be admitted by the Tribunal. Dispute to the final authority should be preferred in the manner prescribed under the works contract. Since in the present case it is provided that in the case of abandonment or cancellation or, in any dispute of works contract, the dispute must be raised before the Superintending Engineer within a period of 30 days. On his failure to decide the dispute within 60 days of after decision of the dispute, appeal must be preferred within 30 days, which shall be decided by the Chief Engineer with 30 days. Therefore, if appeal has not been preferred to the final authority in accordance with the terms of the works contract, petition will not be maintainable before the Tribunal. We hold that in Lachmandas (supra) law has not been settled correctly.

12. The petitioner in this petition has tried to satisfy the Tribunal that a legal notice under Section 80 CPC served through petitioners counsel on 12.11.2002 on the "Engineer" who had been named as the final authority to settle the disputes under Clause 67 of the agreement but that has also not brought any results or release of payment. This letter dt.12.11.2002 is the same which is addressed to several other officers including Executive Engineer, Mini Construction Division, M.P. Electricity 8 Board. Whether this Executive Engineer, Mini Construction Division, M.P. Electricity Board is the same authority which is designated in Clause 31 as Executive Engineer (Civil) Engineer of the Division executing the work or not was further to be explained and proved by the petitioner but no such material has been brought on record to prove that the Executive Engineer, Mini Construction Division to whom, notice under Section 80 of CPC has been addressed is the same authority which is envisaged in clause 31 of the agreement.

13. It is further to be observed that after filing quantified claims before the final authority, i.e. Executive Engineer (Civil) Engineer of the division executing the work, the petitioner was required to wait for 90 days for his decision and then he should have filed petition before this Tribunal but here the petitioner has come after 60 days before the Tribunal. Thus the time frame provided in the agreement has not been followed even if the authority to whom notice addressed is treated as final authority for the sake of argument.

14. Petitioner has given an explanation that since the period of three years was to be completed he filed the petition within 60 days but this argument cannot be accepted since no claim is submitted to the final authority as provided in the agreement. The petition is not maintainable, even for the sake of argument if it is treated that a notice was served on the final authority i.e. Executive Engineer Mini Construction Division, the time frame has not been followed and the petition suffers from being premature as it has been filed before completion of 90 days of the service of notice to the final authority. As such in both the ways the petition is not maintainable and deserves to be dismissed and we hold accordingly."

3. Meaning thereby the Tribunal has held in the Reference that the petitioner has not approached the Engineer as per the terms and conditions of the contract and on the contrary approached the Executive Engineer (Civil Engineer) of the Division and therefore it is a premature reference and the petition filed by the petitioner was dismissed. The petitioner being aggrieved by the order passed by the Tribunal came up before this Court and this Court vide order 8 dated 23.04.2010 has dismissed the revision on the ground that the order passed by the Tribunal has become infructuous in the light of the judgment delivered in the case of VA Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. Vs. MPSE Board and another (Civil Appeal No.3746/2005). The order dated 23.04.2010 reads as under:-

"In view of the order passed by the Apex Court in Civil Appeal No.3746 of 2005 (VA Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. Vs. MPSE Board and another) wherein it is directed that the provisions of Madhya Pradesh Madhyastham Adhikaran Adhiniyam, 1983 are to be treated as impliedly overruled, on enactment of Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. In this view of the matter, the impugned award passed by M.P.Arbitration Tribunal is declared as infructuous. The present petition is disposed of accordingly. However, any of the contesting parties would be at liberty to seek its remedy under the provisions of Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 in accordance with law.
The petition thus, stands finally disposed of."

4. A liberty was granted to the petitioner by the High Court to take shelter of the provisions of Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 and consequently, an application was preferred before this Court as AC.No.30/2010 and the same was dismissed by this Court on 04.12.2013.

5. The petitioner being aggrieved by the order passed by this Court in AC No.30/2010 has approached the Hon'ble Supreme Court and the Hon'ble Supreme Court passed the following order which reads as under:-

"In view of the *aforesaid judgment, the learned Single Judge of the High Court has opined that an application for appointment of Arbitrator under Section 11(6) of the 1996 Act**, not maintainable. The said order is under assail in the present appeal.
Mr.Subhash Samvatsar, learned senior counsel appearing for the appellant submits that 8 the order passed by the High Court is absolutely impeccable, but the issue would be whether the appellant would be left without any remedy because it has been guided by the judgments in the field.
Having heard learned counsel for the parties, we direct that tin order to do complete justice, the order dated 23rd April, 2010, passed in Civil Revision No.244 of 2006 be set aside and the said civil revision shall stand revived. We request the High Court to dispose of the civil revision in accordance with law, within a period of six weeks. Needless to say, all questions of facts and law which can be agitated in civil revision under the M.P.Act, are kept open.
Resultantly, the appeal stands disposed of. There shall be no order as to costs"

6. In the light of the aforesaid, this revision filed by the present petitioner against the order i.e. Civil Revision No.244/2006 was revived.

7. Learned counsel for the petitioner vehemently argued before this Court that the Tribunal has erred in law in facts holding that the petition is premature on the ground that the petitioner has not approached the Engineer as provided under Clause 67 which is a clause related to settlement of disputes. She has straightaway drawn the attention of this Court to the work order issued by the respondent which is Annexure P-1 dated 07.02.1998. Paragraphs 8 and 9 of the work order reads as under:-

"8. The Executive Engineer, Mini Civil Dn.,MPEB, Indore shall be the "Engineer" of the work.

9. Necessary work order for this work will be issued by the Engineer."

8. The aforesaid order makes it very clear that the Executive Engineer, Mini Civil Division, MPEB, Indore shall be the Engineer of the work. Undisputedly, the petitioner has raised his claim before the Executive Engineer, Mini Construction Division M.P.Electricity 8 Board.

9. The aforesaid fact has not been disputed by the learend counsel appearing for the M.P. Electricity Board and therefore as the petitioner has approached the Executive Engineer in terms of the agreement executed between the parties, the order passed by the Tribunal deserves to be set aside.

10. Resultantly, the impugned order passed by the Tribunal is set aside. The Tribunal is directed to decide the dispute on merits after hearing both the parties and following the prescribed procedure as provided under the Madhya Pradesh Madhyashtham Adhikaran Adhiniyam, 1983. The parties are directed to appear before the Tribunal on 25th September, 2017. Office is directed to immediately return the record back to the Tribunal enabling the Tribunal to decide the matter on merits.

As the dispute in the present case dates back to the year 1998, the Tribunal is directed to decide the reference within a period of six months from 25th September, 2017. 

     (S.C. Sharma)                             (Alok Verma)
         Judge                                     Judge
